title-group.article-title: Development of temperature controllers for a room deploying the displacement ventilation for heating, ventilating, and air-conditioning

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Mechanical Engineering and Materials Science, Washington University in Saint Louis, Saint Louis, MO, USA
2Research Institute of Intelligent Control and Systems, Harbin Institute of Technology, Harbin, China

author-notes.corresp: Ramesh Agarwal, Department of Mechanical Engineering and Materials Science, Washington University in Saint Louis, Saint Louis, MO 63130, USA. Email: rka@wustl.edu

abstract.p: By employing the fuzzy control theory and dynamic matrix control method, the controllers for temperature control of a room cooled by a displacement ventilation system are developed. The fluid flow and heat transfer inside the room are calculated by solving the Reynolds-averaged Navier–Stokes equations, including the effects of buoyancy in conjunction with a two-equation realizable k–ε turbulence model. Thus, the physical environment is represented by a nonlinear system of partial differential equations. The system also has a large time delay because of the slowness of the heat exchange. Additionally, the temperature of the exterior wall of the room first increases and then decreases with time during a 24-h period, which acts as a strong disturbance in changing the temperature of the room. The goal of this article is to develop controllers that will maintain the temperature in the room within the specified upper and lower bounds by deploying the displacement ventilation system. In order to solve this temperature control problem, we develop a special fuzzy control method. At the same time, we analyze the peak value of the error and employ the dynamic matrix control method to replace the fuzzy control method with success. The results show that the fuzzy controller is effective in saving energy, and the dynamic matrix control method can contain the error within the specified bounds in the worst situation (when the temperature of the exterior wall is highest). These kinds of fuzzy control and dynamic matrix control methods can also be employed for other heating, ventilating, and air-conditioning systems such as overhead variable air volume system and radiant cooling hydronic system.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: In recent years, due to significant increase in worldwide energy consumption and associated CO2 emissions, there has been increased emphasis on energy efficiency of buildings for both heating and cooling. In many cities around the world, the air-conditioning requirements for cooling the buildings can be excessively high especially during the summer months. As a result, there has been increased emphasis on the study and development of efficient heating, ventilating, and air-conditioning (HVAC) systems. With the development of computer and telecommunication technologies, advanced control strategies can be implemented in operating the HVAC systems in an integrated fashion for commercial buildings to improve their energy efficiency. There have been some results presented in the literature to investigate the thermal comfort and energy performance of buildings, see Thorsell and Bomberg (2011), Saber et al. (2012), and Sailor et al. (2012) and the references therein. But none of these articles discuss the temperature controllers for buildings and their impact on energy performance. In this article, our goal is to develop controllers not only to control the temperature inside the buildings for desired thermal comfort but also to simultaneously minimize the energy usage. There are many types of control techniques that can be employed to control the operation of HVAC systems. To mention a few from the literature, an immune proportional–integral–derivative (PID) adaptive controller has been presented in Peng et al. (2007), which is quite different from the traditional PID controllers (Ang et al., 2005). Previous studies (Cigler and Privara, 2010; Dwivedi and Kaistha, 2009; Gattu and Zafiriou, 1992; Jiang and Huang, 2009; Li and Meng, 2008; Ma et al., 2009, 2010) introduce model predictive control (MPC) method for cooling systems of buildings. In particular, the dynamic matrix control (DMC) method, as one of the MPC methods, has been widely employed in the study of HVAC control systems involving large time delays, see, for instance, Dwivedi and Kaistha (2009) and Jiang and Huang (2009) and the references therein. In other studies (Moon and Kim, 2010), several authors have used artificial neural network (ANN)–based models to control the temperature of a building and have obtained impressive results. The fuzzy control method of Zadeh (1972) has been widely used in many nonlinear control systems; for temperature control inside buildings, a fuzzy control method has been presented in Kajl et al. (1995), which shows promise for temperature control in buildings using different HVAC systems. However, all these studies have limitations with respect to the nature of the disturbance and time delay. They are limited to small disturbance in temperature as well as small time delay in heat exchange. It remains an important and challenging problem to design better controllers, which can keep the temperature stable in a smaller time interval as well as result in more savings in energy.

In this article, we develop controllers for temperature control inside a room within a desired band of temperatures for comfort. The details of the geometry of the room and the HVAC system based on displacement ventilation (DV) for cooling the room are taken from Lee et al. (2010). The control of HVAC system is difficult since this system has no heater, which means that we can only cool the room but cannot heat it. In addition, the time delay in heat exchange also exists in the system. All these factors make it difficult in achieving the temperature control objective using the methods described in the references listed above. After many computational experiments, we have determined and developed some effective methods to solve this control problem. An improved PID controller is designed to control the system, if the exterior wall temperature is not very high compared to the desired temperature inside the room. When the exterior wall temperature increases beyond a certain value, the error becomes increasingly greater. For solving this problem, a fuzzy controller is designed as a global controller to control the system, which can contain the control error in a small interval. Finally, a DMC controller is designed to control the error for the worst situation of very large external wall temperature.

This article is organized as follows. The model for the room and the DV HVAC system is introduced in section “Fluid flow simulation in the room.” The exterior wall temperature wave form for temperature variation during the day is introduced in section “Exterior wall temperature wave form.” In section “Controller design,” several types of controllers are introduced and designed for the HVAC system, namely, the PID controller, the fuzzy controller, and the DMC controller. The implementation example is provided in section “Results.” Finally, we conclude this article in section “Conclusions.”

sec.title: Fluid flow simulation in the room
sec.p: The flow field inside the room with and without DV was simulated by the computational fluid dynamics (CFD) software FLUENT, which solves the unsteady Reynolds-averaged Navier–Stokes (URANS) equations employing the finite-volume method on a collocated grid. In FLUENT, URANS equations are solved using a second-order upwind scheme and the pressure is calculated using the PRESTO scheme. The SIMPLE algorithm is employed for the coupling of the velocity and pressure fields. In our calculations, both the one-equation Spalart–Allmaras (S-A) turbulence model and the two-equation k–ε realizable turbulence model are employed. The S-A model is a simpler turbulence model, which only uses one equation to describe the turbulent eddy viscosity, compared to the k–ε realizable model, which uses two equations to calculate the eddy viscosity. Simulations require the initial starting value of temperature in the room, which was assumed to be 288.16 K, and the air density was taken as 1.225 kg/m3. We computed the flow field using both the S-A and k–ε realizable models on the same grid and found little difference in the results. The geometry of the room and other details of DV are taken from Lee et al. (2010). Figure 1 shows the schematic of the room with the two outlet vents in the ceiling and six inlet vents on the floor. The inlet vents of the room are 6 inch × 9 inch in cross section, which gives an area of 2.25 ft2 for the six vents. The air flow in the room meets the ASHRAE guidelines of air movement. The six inlet vents are placed on the floor near the adiabatic walls. This is done in order to keep the installation of the vents on the floor practical, so that the vents may not be blocked by the furniture and other artifacts in the room. The two outlet vents in the ceiling are 1 ft 6 inch × 1 ft 6 inch in size, giving an area of 4.5 ft2 (0.418 m2) for the two outlet vents.

caption.p: A 3D view of the room with two outlet vents and six inlet vents employed in displacement ventilation.

sec.title: Exterior wall temperature wave form
sec.p: A FLUENT user-defined function (UDF) was created to simulate the temperature of the exterior wall of the room. This temperature curve simulated the exterior wall surface temperature and was based on the American Society of Heating, Refrigerating and Air-Conditioning Engineers’s (ASHRAE) total equivalent temperature difference (TETD) curve given in Donnelly et al. (2008). This curve was scaled by 0.5 about its lowest temperature point to simulate the effect of insulation. A three-dimensional (3D) Cartesian mesh inside the room was generated by GAMBIT, with a uniform grid spacing of 3 inch. Figure 2 shows the change in the exterior wall temperature in 24-h period on a typical summer day in St Louis, Missouri. This exterior wall temperature wave form was employed only to one wall of the room. We do not take into account the changes from 1 day to the next over a period of weeks or months. The goal is to develop controllers for controlling the temperature in the room subjected to a 24-h temperature variation on a typical summer day in St Louis, Missouri.

caption.p: Changes in exterior wall temperature during a day.

sec.title: Controller design
sec.p: In this section, the design of controllers to control the temperature inside the room is presented. There is no heater in the HVAC system and therefore when the temperature is lower than the desired one, the room can only be heated by the environment of the room; this situation is not considered in the controller design. The temperature of the environment in the room is affected by the heat input from the exterior wall; the goal of the controller design is to control the temperature inside the room within a small band for thermal comfort. However, the temperature at the exterior wall can experience large changes in time during the day resulting in large changes in the temperature of the environment of the room, which makes it difficult to control the temperature in a small error interval. In this study, the temperature controller was designed and coded into a FLUENT UDF, so that it maintained a band of temperatures deemed comfortable. We introduce three kinds of controllers—the PID controller that is a model-free local controller, the fuzzy controller that is a mode-free global controller, and the DMC that is a mode-based local controller.

On the other hand, if the temperature of the environment changes dramatically (e.g. if the temperature becomes higher than 316 K), the controller will not be able to control the temperature in the room within the desired band, and it will result in large fluctuations in the temperature of the room because of the action of the controller.

sec.title: Fuzzy controller
sec.p: There are two reasons for considering the fuzzy control technique for our HVAC system: (a) the HVAC system is a nonlinear system, and therefore, it is difficult to find a proper state-space model to describe it and (b) the system is not easily controllable because of large variations in temperature. When the temperature of the room becomes lower than the desired, the only way to make the temperature of the room increase is through heat exchange from the room environment automatically. Furthermore, there exists time delay in the system, which makes the system more difficult to control. Following the approach in Passino and Yurkovich (1998), we present the following method to control the HVAC systems.

The fuzzy controller for the HVAC system is shown in Figure 3. The controller has four main components: (a) the “rule-based” knowledge component in the form of a set of rules that provide guidance how to best control the system, (b) the inference mechanism to evaluate which control rules are relevant at a particular time and then decide what the input to the HVAC system (plant) should be, (c) the fuzzification interface that changes the inputs that can be calculated using the rules in the rule-based component, and (d) the defuzzification interface that converts the conclusions reached by the inference mechanism in the form of inputs to the plant.

sec.p: To design the fuzzy controller, we must gather the information on how the decision maker should act in the closed-loop system. Thus, we must define the if-then rules first such as “If the plant output and reference input are behaving in a certain manner, then the plant input should be this particular value.” A whole set of such “if-then” rules is then loaded into the rule-based component of the fuzzy controller, which should cover all instances of time.

sec.title: Choosing fuzzy controller inputs and outputs
sec.p: The fuzzy controller is designed to automate the task of controlling the system the way a human expert would control. Thus, we must know what information we really need for this purpose. For the HVAC system, we use the following inputs

In equation (4), r(k) is the desired temperature of the room (we set r(k) ≡ 296.6 K) and y(k) is actual temperature of the room. Thus, e(k) is the error between r(k) and y(k), and ec(k) is the change in e(k) given by equation (5). There are many other choices; however, when we add additional inputs into the system, the rule-base increases significantly. The above two inputs are enough to control the problem.

There is one more referenced input in the system; it is the temperature of the exterior wall. When this temperature increases to a certain value, the controller cannot keep the error in a small interval. Therefore, we need to design another controller and switch to this controller when the temperature of the exterior wall increases beyond a certain value. There is also time delay, when the HVAC system and the environment of the room exchange the air to cool the room. Therefore, we need to switch the controller after this time delay. The only output of the controller is the flux of the cold air from the HVAC system, which is controlled by the jets issuing from the HVAC system.

sec.title: Translating knowledge into rule-base
sec.p: In order to develop a fuzzy controller to replace the expert to control the system, the control knowledge needs to be translated into rules that will be loaded into the rule-based component of the controller shown in Figure 3. Mathematical descriptions of the rules are needed to replace the linguistic descriptions. For our system, “error” is denoted as e(k), “change-in-error” is denoted by ec(k), and the “mass flux” is denoted by u(k). The “error” and “change-in-error” take the following values: {“neglarge,”“negmid,”“negsmall,”“zero,”“possmall,”“posmid,”“poslarge,”“posverylarge”} and “mass flux” takes on the following values: {“zero,”“possmall,”“posmid,”“poslarge,”“posverylarge”}, which represent {0, 0.07, 0.14, 0.2524, 0.5}.

Note that we use “neglarge” as an abbreviation for “negative large in size” and so on for the other variables. Also note that “mass flux” does not have negative values, which implies that the temperature will be controlled such that it can only decrease. For a short mathematical description, we could use integers: “−3” to represent “neglarge,”“−2” to represent “negmid,”“−1” to represent “negsmall,”“0” to represent “zero,”“1” to represent “possmall,”“2” to represent “posmid,”“3” to represent “poslarge,” and 4 to represent “posverylarge.” We are not, for example, associating “1” with any particular number of radians of error. The use of the numbers quantifies the sign of the error and indicates the size in relation to the other values. Using the definitions given above, we provide some control knowledge as follows:

list-item.p: When the temperature in the room is on higher side, turn up the jets to increase the input mass flux of cold air.
When the temperature in the room is lower, turn down the jets to decrease the input mass flux of cold air.
When the temperature in the room is very low (lower than desired), turn off the jets to have zero input mass flux of air.

sec.p: Now, we specify a set of rules that capture the expert’s knowledge about how to control the plant. We can get the rule from Table 1; for example, if e(k) = −1 and ec(k) = 0, we get u(k) = 0, which means that if error is “negsmall” and change-in-error is “zero,” then “mass flux” is also “zero.”

sec.title: DMC method
sec.p: DMC has been shown to be an effective advanced control method in many industrial process control applications and has recently been extended to the control systems that often have large time delay and uncertainty. Our HVAC system has these characteristics. The fuzzy controller described in section “Fuzzy controller” works quite well most of the time; however, when the temperature of the exterior wall is near the peak value, the performance of the controller is not good enough. Therefore, under these conditions, we consider designing a DMC controller, which is a model-based control method (Dwivedi and Kaistha, 2009; Jiang and Huang, 2009). Such a controller has been never been designed for an HVAC system before.

sec.title: Model foundation
sec.p: In the DMC-based controller, we first need to determine a system model. The model in DMC is determined by the step response, which is similar to the traditional model composed of the difference equation. From the change of exterior wall temperature in Figure 2, we know that the worst situation for the controller is when the exterior wall temperature is 340 K. Thus, we set the exterior wall temperature equal to 340 K without control, and when the room temperature is near 340 K, we give a step signal to mass flux (0.05) to make the HVAC system cool the room. At this time, we can obtain the step response data that can be used as a model; it is shown in Figure 6.

sec.title: Remark 2
sec.p: In reality, the external wall temperature is usually unknown. For the fuzzy control method, this lack of information does not influence the controller design. However, the controller error cannot be estimated. On the other hand, for the DMC method, it is impossible to design a controller for this situation, since the DMC method is a model-based controller. Although the external wall temperature is unknown, based on the actual observations over a long period of time, the upper bound and the lower bound of the external wall temperature can be estimated. Thus, by assuming that the upper bound and the lower bound of the external wall temperature are known, the fuzzy control method can be applied directly, and the controller error can be estimated by CFD simulations. The DMC method can also be used; however, it needs to find the model every 10 or 20 K interval. The designed controllers are switched based on changes in the external wall temperature during different time intervals.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: In this section, we employ the fuzzy controller and DMC controller to control the temperature in the room for the DV HVAC system.

sec.title: Fuzzy controller
sec.p: Using the parameters and data from the previous section “Fuzzy controller,” we design two fuzzy controllers. One is designed to control the system when the exterior wall temperature is lower than 323.5 K; the other is designed when the exterior wall temperature is higher than 323.5 K. Both the DV HVAC system and the exterior wall temperature influence the temperature of the room with different delays, since the temperature in the room changes slowly. Based on the computational experiments using the external wall temperature described by Figure 2, we obtain the heat exchange delay of 2.3 h. Thus, when we switch the controllers, this heat exchange delay must be considered. The heat exchange delay due to the jets from the HVAC system is very small, which can be overcome by the design of the fuzzy controller. Tables 4 and 5 are the controller rule tables for the whole system employing the “biggest value” defuzzification method. Figure 7 shows that our controller can keep the temperature of the room between 295.8 and 297.4 K, while the controller in Lee et al. (2010) can only keep the temperature between 294.67 and 298.25 K. From Figure 7, it can be concluded that the fuzzy controller developed in this article gives superior results than those given in Lee et al. (2010). Figure 8 shows the comparison of the cost of the cold air needed to maintain the temperature in the room within a prescribed band, when the fuzzy controller and the controller in Lee et al. (2010) are used. It can be inferred from Figure 8 that the fuzzy controller saves more energy compared to the controller used in Lee et al. (2010) because the fuzzy controller is a nonlinear controller and is well designed; on the other hand, the structure of controller in Lee et al. (2010) is very simple, which does not consider the delay in the system.

sec.p: There are three advantages of the fuzzy controller. First, it is easy to design a fuzzy controller by the control knowledge. Second, the fuzzy controller is a global controller, which can be used in the entire temperature control process. Third, the fuzzy controller is a robust controller, which can guarantee the stability of the system with the disturbance. The disadvantages of the fuzzy controller are as follows. If there is no control knowledge, it is hard to design the controller. The membership function is designed by experience, and different membership functions can lead to different control performance. If we want to further improve the precision of the controller, the controller becomes more and more complex and therefore may become difficult to use in real-time control systems. sec.title: DMC controller
sec.p: In this section, we present the results using the DMC controller. As shown in Figure 9, the error in the temperature is nearly the same as that in Figure 7. By the DMC method, we can control the temperature between 295.8 and 297.5 K, and if it is well designed, then the error in temperature can be further reduced. From Figure 8, it can be seen that the fuzzy controller saves more energy compared to DMC controller and that used in Lee et al. (2010), because the DMC controller uses less input to get better performance. Comparing the performance of fuzzy controller and DMC controller, we know that the average temperature in DMC controller is lower than that in fuzzy controller. Thus, the DMC controller costs more energy. The advantages of the DMC controller are as follows. First, it is an optimal controller using the minimal input to get better performance. Second, it is a self-adapting controller, which changes as the input changes. There are two disadvantages of the DMC controller. First, the DMC controller is a local controller, which can only guarantee the stability of the system in a local area. Second, the DMC controller is a model-based controller, whose model is linear. But our system is a nonlinear system, and thus, there are errors if the linear model describes the nonlinear system. When the disturbance becomes larger and larger, we need to find another model and design a new controller. sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: This article has developed and employed PID, fuzzy, and DMC controllers for controlling the temperature in a room using a DV HVAC system without heater. This cooling system is uncontrollable when the temperature inside the room is lower than the expected one. It is a nonlinear system with large disturbance, which has delays both in the control variable and in the environment disturbance. By a proper estimation of the environment disturbance and the heat exchange delay in it, we have designed the fuzzy controllers to control the system for different intensities of environment disturbance. The fuzzy controllers control the temperature of the room quite well. We have also designed a DMC controller to control the system when the temperature of the exterior wall is near the peak value. The control results using three different controllers are analyzed and compared. Both the fuzzy controller and the DMC controller perform quite well and result in energy savings compared to those reported in Lee et al. (2010).
